Had levoled off at 120 feet when he passed directly

port, and starboard - all aft however. Really rattled

pumping. Succeeded in scraping along and probably
stirring up lonty of mud. His next charge was close
aft and caused a flash of fire and smoke from the
control cubicle. Stopped all motors and lay on
bottom while electricians inspected for damage.
The escort had been a distinct bush loaguor up to
the tino wo lod with cur chin, but he had us playing
his game now. Ho mado oight single runs using his
fathometer and laying them sot deep in the mud all
around us. He dropped from one to three on each run
and they went off from 40 to 70 seconds after ho had
pass od ovor. The old ship would hop from fox hole
to fox hole as cach went off. We took some water
through the storn plano packing glands and through
the hoad flood valves which spun to full open on each
charge. No hull damage tho. I take my hat off to the
Electric Boat Company. They roally built a tough hull
into this ship. Ho was making 15 knots on his runs,
hauling out to about 3,000 yards to lot the mud settle
after each drop.

U.S.S. COBIA - Fifth War Patrol - report of. (cont)
C -
WEATHER
Weather was in general accord with Sailing Directions,
seas being calm and skies partly overcast with frequent rain
squalls. The period 4-8 June found us on the outskirts of
a tropical disturbance with heavy overcast and #34 seas.
D - TIDAL INFORMATION
Information contained in Sailing Directions was accurate.
A 2.5 easterly set was encountered on the one day spent sub-
merged south of Pulo Obi.
E - NAVIGATIONAL AIDES
No navigational lights were lighted. Loran was used in
all areas north of the Barrier and results were good. Koh
Tang Island was found by radar and celestial fixes to be
approximately one mile east of its position as shown on chart
HO-3138.

U.S.S. COBIA - Fifth War Patrol - report of. (cont)
G - AIRCRAFT CONTACTS
Aircraft patrols in the Siam Gulf were few and far between.
No night flying planes were encountered on this patrol. The
two convoys encountered each had a close air patrol of one
float plane - Jake during daylight hours.
On May 26th, after keying the SD radar intermittently
because of close partial overcast, we were bombed by a float
plane. A transport plano was sighted on June 5th south of
Pulo Panjang. His actions indicated that he was patrolling.
North of Bawean we were bombed by a float plane that
broke out of a cloud. SD had been in use sparingly earlier
during the day. He called out a Betty to play "cat and
mouse" with us.

U.S.S. COBIA (SS245) - Report of Fifth War Patrol.
The fifth war patrol of the COBIA, conducted in the Gulf of
Siam, was of forty days duration, twenty-seven of which were spent in the
assigned area. The Commanding Office of the COBIA was coordinator of
attack group consisting at various times of the HAMMERHEAD, H.M.S. SUPREMME,
HAWKBILL, BULLHEAD, and BERGALL. Patrol was terminated due to expenditure of
torpedoes.
2.
Area coverage was excellent. Many contacts were made with
junks; one which was flying Siamese colors was sunk by a well conducted gun
attack on 30 May. There were two contacts on convoys with ships worthy of
torpedo fire both of which were closed for attack. Of interest is the fact
that no aircraft contacts were made at night.
3.
TORPEDO ATTACK NO. 1: On 14 May a day periscope attack was
made on a minesweeper escort for a medium AK%; five steam torpedoes were fired
on large track, with large gyros for no hits. This attack was ruined by a
telephone talker mistaking an order for the assistant approach officer as an
order to change the keel depth. This escort later, after an hours search,
found the COBIA and subjected her to a severe depth charge attack. This
attack forced the COBIA to bottom; put all torpedo tubes out of commission
and caused a small fire in the maneuvering room when some foreign material
fell into the control cubicle. After repairs were made the COBIA surfaced
and later was able to draw off the escort and allow the HAMMERHEAD to sink
the AK.
TORFEDO ATTACK NO. 2: On 8 June a night surface attack was
made on a convoy consisting of two tankers and one unidentified escort. Four
electrie torpedoes were fired on 90° track, gyros 208, depth set 6 feet,
torpedo run 3300 yards. No explosions were obtained. One torpedo was seen
to broach and one dud hit was heard.
TORPEDO ATTACK NO. 3:
Torpedo Attack No. 3 followed immediately
on the same convoy after a reload. Six steam torpedoes were fired on an 80°
track, 2300 yards run, gyro zero, depth set 6 feet for two hits. The large
tanker was seen to sink. Two torpedoes in this salvo were suspected to be
erratic.

U.S.S. COBIA (SS245) - Report of Fifth War Patrol
Comment on.
1.
The Fifth War Patrol of the COBIA, under the com-
mand of Commander A. L. BECKER, U.S.N., was conducted in the
GULF OF SIAM. Activity was co-ordinated at various times with
H.M.S. SUPREME, U.S.S. HANTERHEAD, HABILL, BERGALL, and BULL-
HEAD. The patrol was of forty days duration, trenty seven of
which were spent in the assigned area, and was terminated be-
cause of the expenditure of torpedoes.
2.
One gun and six torpedo attacks were made upon the
enemy, and three ships were sunk. Of particular excellence was
the series of attacks made during the carly morning hours of
8 June. Dotermined to attack the enemy at an unexpected point,
COBIA proceeded into an arca ton fathoms deep and nearly two
hours run inside of the twenty fathom curve. Upon locating
enemy targets he executed a series of torpedo attacks which
sank two valuable enemy tankers. This same aggressive spirit
was exhibitod on 14 May when COPIA unsuccessfully attac'ed a CM
YABYAMA Class (EU), and then reloaded and commenced a second at-
tack. After being detected she was subjected to a very severe
counter attack which drove her to the bottom in 148 feet of water.
3.
It is of interest to note the description of the
unusual denth charge attack of 14 May after COBI had settled to
the bottom. The depth charges were believed to be set deep and
then droned into the mud because the explosion occurred from
forty to seventy seconds after the charge had been droned. It
was a source of great satisfaction to COBIA to be informed on
19 May by HAWKBILL that she had sunk the YEYAMA (EU) shortly
after this attack upon COBIA,. HAWKBILL has since identified
this vessel as the HATSUTAKA rather than the YAEYAMA.
